description: From Middle English garland, garlaunde, gerland, from Old French garlande, garlaunde, gerlande, guerlande (compare French guirlande), from Frankish *wierlōn, *wieralōn, a frequentative form of Frankish *wierōn (“to adorn, bedeck”), from *wiera (“a gold thread”), from or related to Proto-Germanic *wīraz.
Akin to Old High German wieren (“to adorn”), Old High German wiara (“gold thread”). More at wire.

entries.meaning: A wreath, especially one of plaited flowers or leaves, worn on the body or draped as a decoration.
examples: Bestow a Garland only on a Bier

entries.meaning: An accolade or mark of honour.
(mining) A metal gutter placed round a mineshaft on the inside, to catch water running down inside the shaft and run it into a drainpipe.
(dated) A book of extracts in prose or poetry; an anthology.
examples: They [ballads] began to be collected into little miscellanies under the name of garlands.

entries.meaning: The top; the thing most prized.
(nautical) A sort of netted bag used by sailors to keep provisions in.
(nautical) A grommet or ring of rope lashed to a spar for convenience in handling.

verbs.description: garland (third-person singular simple present garlands, present participle garlanding, simple past and past participle garlanded)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To deck or ornament something with a garland.
(transitive) To form something into a garland.
